Hyperelastic#

(libela.hyperelastic)

Symbolic strain-energy models for hyperelastic materials. Each class defines a strain-energy function \(W(I_1, I_2, J, \ldots)\) and inherits symbolic stress evaluation from the operations mix-in.

Note

This module relies on sympy for symbolic computation and numpy for numerical operations. See the SymPy documentation and the NumPy documentation for more details.

See Material Model Catalogue for mathematical background and Hyperelastic Materials for usage examples.

Material Models#

Model

API Reference

Equation

Description

Neo-Hookean

hyperelastic.neohookean

\(W = \frac{\mu}{2}(I_1-3)\) \(W_{\mathrm{NI}} = \frac{\mu}{2}(\bar I_1-3) + W_{\mathrm{vol}}\)

Simple, isotropic, incompressible model for rubber-like materials.

Mooney-Rivlin

hyperelastic.mooneyrivlin

\(W = C_1(\bar I_1-3) + C_2(\bar I_2-3) + W_{\mathrm{vol}}\)

Captures nonlinearity in rubber elasticity.

Yeoh

hyperelastic.yeoh

\(W = C_1 (\bar I_1-3) + C_2 (\bar I_1-3)^2 + C_3 (\bar I_1-3)^3 + W_{\mathrm{vol}}\)

Good for modeling large deformations.

Polynomial

hyperelastic.polynomial

\(W = \sum_{p,q} C_{pq} (\bar I_1-3)^p (\bar I_2-3)^q + W_{\mathrm{vol}}\)

General, flexible form for fitting experimental data.

Klosner-Segal

hyperelastic.klosnersegal

\(W = c_{11}(I_1-3) + c_{21}(I_2-3) + c_{22}(I_2-3)^2 + c_{23}(I_2-3)^3\)

Four-term model for advanced fitting.

Functions & Methods#

Function/Method

API Reference

Description

Example

fit

hyperelastic.fit

Fit model parameters to experimental data.

 
model.fit(data)

stress

hyperelastic.stress

Compute the Cauchy or 2nd Piola-Kirchhoff stress for a given deformation.

 
stress = model.stress(F)

strain

hyperelastic.strain

Compute strain invariants or tensors.

 
I1, I2 = model.strain(F)

energy

hyperelastic.energy

Return the symbolic strain-energy function for the model.

 
W = model.energy()

deformation_protocols

hyperelastic.operations

Standard loading protocols (uniaxial, biaxial, shear) for stress evaluation.

 
model.stress(F, protocol="uniaxial")

operations

hyperelastic.operations

All models inherit symbolic and numeric operations from libela.hyperelastic.operations.

See Operations

Example#

from libela.hyperelastic import neohookean
import numpy as np

F = np.eye(3)  # Deformation gradient
model = neohookean(mu=1.0, lam=1.0)
stress = model.stress(F)
print(stress)
